questions.question_text: Which Cisco data center switch can support a 4-RU physical space requirement and also support FEX, Layer 2 and Layer 3, converged FCoE, and up to ninety- six 40-Gigabit Ethernet ports?

comments.content:
Nevermind, answered my own question.

"The Cisco Nexus 7000 4-Slot chassis with two I/O module slots supports up to 96 x 1 and 10 Gigabit Ethernet ports, 12 x 40 Gigabit Ethernet ports and 4 x 100 Gigabit Ethernet ports."

discussion.content: Confused as to why this isn't the 7004?
Is this really a question off the exam? They can't possibly expect us to believe this level of detail can they????

questions.question_text: Which device can provide FCoE connectivity?

discussion.content:
Cisco 2901 Integrated Services Router - ISRs don't support storage networking
Cisco Nexus 2224TP Fabric Extender are dumb devices and don't run FCoE
Cisco Nexus 5548 Switch ** correct **
Cisco ASA 5510 Firewall - firewalls aren't storage/SAN devices

questions.question_text: Which two MAC addresses are valid? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
MAC addresses are made up of 12 hexadecimal characters separated one of the three methods below. 

EXAMPLES:

18-04-37-cb-62-20
1804.37cb.6220
18:04:37:cb:62:20

comments.content: My vote is B, F, and H. E is incorrect because the password is optional and does not 'need' to be set on a client device. G is incorrect not only because the default is vlan.dat but also because the non-default data is in startup-config.

discussion.content: "...understand that NX-OS is different than an IOS-based switch. In an IOS-based switch the VLAN and VTP databases were stored in the vlan.dat file found in flash memory. Deleting this file would set the VLAN configurations back to factory default. We want to take a different approach when configuring our VLANs and VTP on our NX-OS switches and understanding where the information is stored. First, the default configuration file for NX-OS is vlan.dat in bootflash but also the VLANs and VTP information is stored in startup-config."

Also, answer H is correct per this Cisco website. If the answer had said that it CANNOT support vtp pruning, then H would have to be ruled out. Maybe someone left off the word CANNOT???: It says very near the top that VTP pruning can be configured on Cisco NX-OS devices.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/sw/5_x/nx-os/layer2/configuration/guide/Cisco_Nexus_7000_Series_NX-OS_Layer_2_Switching_Configuration_Guide_Release_5-x_chapter5.html#task_9F3D0D0F68174167B51599C4CB08B570

I agree with answer F, as that is stated on Cisco's website:

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/sw/nx-os/layer2/configuration/guide/b_Cisco_Nexus_7000_Series_NX-OS_Layer_2_Switching_Configuration_Guide/b_Cisco_Nexus_7000_Series_NX-OS_Layer_2_Switching_Configuration_Guide_chapter_0101.html

I agree with answer B, as you need to be able to configure VTP in any of the VDCs.

questions.question_text: What are three important factors when configuring VTP on the Cisco Nexus switching platform? (Choose three.)

choices.F: In VTP server mode, the device will store VLAN information in bootflash.
choices.A: VLAN 1 must be disabled on the trunk port in order for VTP to work properly.
choices.E: For a device operating in VTP client mode, the password and domain name must be properly set.
choices.B: The VDC administrator or network administrator must enable VTP on the device.
choices.D: It does not matter which VDC you are working in when you configure VTP on the Cisco Nexus 7000.
choices.G: Per device, VTP configuration is stored in a file named vtp.conf.
choices.C: VTP is enabled on all trunk ports by default.
choices.H: VTP pruning can be used on Cisco NX-OS devices.

choices.E: The command copy running-config startup-config will save changes to the VLAN database.
choices.C: VLAN licensing is required for use.
choices.A: Software updates are disruptive to VLANs.
choices.B: VLANs with the same number are unique to their VDC.
choices.D: To change VLAN information, the administrator must be at the switch (config) # prompt.

discussion.content:
Is answer D wrong because you first have to access the vlan to make changes, which puts you at switch(config-vlan)# 

Is that why D is wrong????

questions.question_text: Which two statements about configuring VLANs on the Cisco Nexus 7000 platform are true? (Choose two.)
